title: The perfect XBLOOM companion.
body: Have you tried xbloom? The new specialty coffee pod? It's a brewing pod that comes with premium whole beans that you grind at home and then brew with their fancy coffee brewing robot? No? Could be it's out of your price range? Well that could be true, but I discovered today that the pods are the perfect size for brewing with the Makita Coffee Maker. I made myself two wonderful coffees today with the Makita and was completely stunned this thing is awesome. The coffee was even too hot to drink which was impressive for this small form factor. The xbloom pods come with 15g of whole beans and I just grind them sort of medium coarse and put them back in the xbloom pod. Next you want to insert the whole paper and ground coffee into your Makita Mesh and close the lid on top and insert into the Makita coffee slot and brew a coffee. So the xbloom pods are sort of marketed as specialty coffees with dialed in recipes for brewing, but they also use premium coffee origins too, so it's a great way to try some special single origins roasts that you haven't tried before. They also have blends and such. The coffee it excels at brewing is sort of medium roast with a chocolatey and fruity flavor, but with the high heat output of this Makita, it could really perform well with Lighter Roasts too.

title: A Novelty at Best
body: It's a cute idea, but not designed for someone at a jobsite or someone camping, truly. The cup is very small. Tea cup small. Co-worker even said I should stick out my pinky while drinking from it. He exaggerates a little, but it is a small cup if it's designed to be used out on a jobsite. Nothing in the description said my 18V Makita BL1815 batteries would not work, but they did not. Luckily I had BL1820B which did work, but each battery was only able to brew one cup. So for 30-45 minutes of charge time, plus 10 minutes of brewing I get two small cups of coffee. Again, not exactly jobsite friendly. Another issue I've found is that although it does come with two "filter" holder/adapters, if you want to use the pads/pods they are extremely difficult to find. At least where I live down south. I did order some off of Amazon, but used just regular coffee since they have not arrived. Although this coffee maker is the right idea, the build, and performance of it are just not practical in any real world setting for me. The best way I could describe this is: "cute" or a novelty. title: It's got issues
body:
It will brew a cup of coffee in a pinch, but it's got issues.

1. With a brand new Makita brand battery fully.charged I brews one cup of coffee. Not two as stated.
2. It does not draw down all of the water. So you have to use more water assuming about 1-2 ounces will go unused.
3. Its not particularly hot. I typically use a hit tap (well below boiling as it should be for coffee) but this is lower temperature than a hot tap or Keurig. But it is decent. Just plan on drinking your coffee quickly.
4. Part of the reason it isn't that hot is that it is slow. This is actually stated in the product info. Instead of a quick 60s brew like Keurig it's about 4 minutes. So some of the coffee has already been cooling in the cup for 4 minutes when you pick it up.

It does come with a basket plus filter for coffee or could be used for loose tea leaves. It also includes a second basket without fine filter that would work for paper coffee pods or tea bags. On the inside top cover is a small scoup you can use to scoup coffee grinds. Finally it does include the Makita stainless mug as shown.

I like the mug but it does not include a spill proof cover. That feels like a huge miss for job site coffee.

It's a decent first gen product. I'm hopeful they can improve on it with higher voltage and amp-hour batteries in the future. As an aside the Makita 18v charger is horrible. I have a separately purchase set with two batteries and charger. The lights indicate the no charge red then remove battery and reinsert and it's solid green. It's also about 4 times larger and heavier than DeWalt, Bosch, Skill, Craftsman, and HPT chargers all of which I have and use regularly.

If Makita teams is reading this:
- include a case. Semi soft would be good
- spill proof cup lid
- get it to drain all of the water from reservoir
- designs new 18v charger. THIS IS THE DEAL BREAKER.

Based on the horrible batteries and charger I'd recommendfolks not buy this. There are car/truck portable DC/AC inverters and canister water heater solutions that will make better coffee.

title: Not what I was hoping for...
body:
I was thinking this would be a good office coffee maker/road-trip caffeine fix/garage coffee maker. Since I'm already on the Makita platform, this seemed like a good fit for me.

The good points are: The coffee comes out good. It's hot and it flavourful. It's battery powered, so you can have a cup of coffee anywhere you think to bring this. Finally, on a 5ah battery, I can brew 4 cups (200ml or less).

The not-so good points are that it's messy. It dribbles after every cup and do not fill the basket over half-full, or you will end up with more than just a dribble. After each cup, you'll need to rinse the mug as there's a thick coating of coffee fines that make that last mouthful...unpleasant..should you make that mistake. You'll also need to clean out the filter and the filter holder as it's going to be coated in coffee grounds...meaning you can use this once and then clean-up is required before using it for the next cup.

You also get the pod holder, which is apparently compatible with Senseo coffee pods. this might be worth investigating, but being in Canada, these are about as common as hens teeth.

When I consider other options, a camp-stove, small pot and an Aeropress cost less, makes a full mug of coffee, is much cleaner overall, while still offering the portability and "cordless" flexibility...not to mention, it's faster overall.

Overall, I'm not seeing the value in real use that I was hoping for when I bought this.
